name: rockysbebe
comment: Maybe as a sitcom with the perfect actors this would be good but for a book it did not work for me.  I found all the characters to be ridiculous.  The whole idea was too unbelievable and every character to be so dysfunctional.

name: William M.
comment: I went to all the 1 stars to find out why some didn't like this book, and they all pretty much agree with me.It's annoying. The people are too stupid to hold the jobs they have. I'm not sure where the guy went after he shot himself and why there wasn't a trail of blood leading the cops to him....and then I didn't care.The Bank Teller, in reality, would not be able to hold a job in any field the way she was written. To me a character, written as dumb or as sarcastic as possible, still has to hold a level of probability of existence in the real world. Otherwise it's just a cartoon, and this book is not supposed to be a cartoon.Is it?

name: S. Vanhoose
comment: I loved Ove, so decided to pick this up as my next book to read.  This was probably one of my favorite books I have read in a long time!  Wow!  The author has this amazing knack of keeping a story silly and lighthearted and quirky while at the same time dealing with deep truths of human life and psychology.  He balances this amazingly throughout the book.  I will say that if you are triggered by a nasty divorce or by suicide themes, read with care.  But otherwise it is just a fabulously written book with a very unique plot line and a very unique style that combines goofy, almost trite at times, humor with some very realistic and serious life issues.  READ THIS.

name: Laurie Malmstrom
comment: This book has an off-beat humor that was unsettling at first. Very clever and with surprising twists. I’ve never read a book that could be so funny, uncomfortable, tragic, and up-lifting all the the same time! It was very appropriately released in September—suicide awareness month. It reveals how deeply connected we all are.

name: JBPT
comment: I enjoyed all of the other novels by this author, but am having a really hard time getting through this book. The characters are too ridiculous to be remotely believable or funny; I just find myself annoyed.  I'll try to finish it, since I spent the money, but am not hopeful it will get any better.

name: Mom of 2
comment: At first, I was a little annoyed at the lightheartedness and silly tone of the book. I was afraid it would persist throughout the novel, and I felt a little pandered to.Fortunately, the lightheartedness is there to balance out the serious nature of what is really being discussed. The moments of humor, too silly to ever be real, are there to balance the awful reality of depression, anxiety, divorce, death, loneliness, guilt, and suicide.This is a book that begs to be read twice, as there is much to revisit through new eyes.I read this 3 days loo late to be chosen for my yearly pick for book club. ($@!!$&)!!

name: Amazon Customer
comment: The book had too much rambling about nothing and the story was very strange... It wasn't like his other books that I really enjoyed.

name: PLGray
comment: In the time of COVID, anxious people provided a respite. I have been having a hard time reading books these past few months. Then along comes this book.  I was a bit confused at the beginning where different people and stories were presented. Then the larger story unfolds. F Backman has an amazing ability to let us get to know his characters.We learn their quirks or flaws and coping mechanisms.  Then he lets us see their relationships with one another. It's not long until you look forward to reading and wanting to be with the characters and knowing what happens.  Here is a heart warming story that isn't sappy but very satisfying. Highly recommend.

name: LilyBelle
comment: As usual a lovely story with depth of character and multiple pieces of wisdom that leave you thinking long after you have finished the book. My only issue is that just about half the characters are contrarians and it becomes tiresome. Bordering on annoying. I found myself skimming in spots. At the end you discover the reason for their behavior but it was just too much. I believe 100 less pages would have been perfect.

name: Linda Romer
comment: I really liked Anxious People. A very interesting novel with a group of interesting people. I liked all the characters and their stories. This book has plenty of twists and turns that will surprise you. I enjoyed the relationships of the couples and enjoyed getting into the individuals heads. A very human story with faults, joys and tears. My favorite part of the story is when three ladies are in the walk in closet having a heart to heart conversation. I will be reading more of this Authors work.I give Anxious People 4 stars for its heartfelt read.I would recommend this book to fans of Fiction.

name: movievixen
comment: I queried “Anxious People” as I read the book yet could not stop reading. I found the book funny, clever, often bewildering, even frustrating but also charming and, ultimately, really smart. Smart is what kept me going and, with each page, I became more invested in the wonderful characters. Towards the ending, it was gratitude I felt toward Fredric Backman for his generosity, his quiet joy and deep angst; his gift of sharing the truths we all experience daily in our lives. He snuck up on me. I found myself teary-eyed and with new perspective or, perhaps renewed perspective , as I finished this book. “Anxious People” is a gift to us all.

name: Kindle Customer
comment: Anxiety is the process of slowing down emotional responses. It can incapacitate  an I individual as they spiral toward the bottom. The author tells a story filled with hopeful people who change their own course. This author defines resilience. His people are real and have the same human afflictions  as any other human.Never give up.  There is always a way up and or someone to catch you.

name: Shud49
comment: Something I rarely, very rarely do. Got 51% through the book and could not finish it. I loved every quirky, compelling character. Then after a while they became stagnant and very boring. I loved this author’s “Beartown” and “A Man Called Ove”. Not this one.

name: Sheila
comment: So often when I've read all of an author their books become predictable but not Bachman.  He hasn't written the same book twice.  I really liked Anxious People, as much as Beartown and A Man Called Ove.  This is a story I entered and was rewarded by the trust of the characters as they revealed who they were.  It is a fun read during a tough 'pandemic' time and I didn't want the book to end.

name: Retired in Florida
comment: Bachman has the Scandinavian dry, sardonic humor.  He says things we may think, some sad.  But he puts a great twist to it.  You recognize the characters and love them.  Like family, they all have their quirks but sometimes manage to pull together.  The premise is a running, unsuccessful bank robber who hides with people in an open house showing and holds the group hostage.  They are all anixious, including the bank robber and the police.  What a dilemma??!!This is the first book I can remember my entire book club loving.  Hard to please a bunch of smart retired women.  I highly recommend it

name: J. Kuntze
comment: There are many writers who have something to say, and some who actually get published and enjoy a bit of notoriety. A few turn out to be more than one-hit wonders, but only a small handful are true masters of their craft. They can tell a story that makes you laugh and wonder and cry and cringe; they can make their readers see themselves in every character they create; they somehow use just the right words in just the right order, no more, no less, and weave a tale that is powerful and perfect.Mr. Backman has done it again with “Anxious People”. This should be the next book you read.

name: N. Dahiya
comment: It started of as a simple disconnected story, I thought the dots would never connect and it’s a very superficial read.It made a about turn a third of the way and then kept becoming engrossing and with so much depth, one could drown trying to decipher the meaning.Has a lot of truth to what some may call cliches. I would recommend this to anyone who reads ... it’s a story about us all. We could identify with any one or more of the circumstances and people in the book.We just have to keep moving on in life always doing our best and believe that we are doing our best.
